items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
	 
	 
Anton Cao
Evergreen Valley High School
Earns Perfect Score on Advanced Placement (AP) Exam - Spring 2015
		 
Anton Cao, an 11th grader at Evergreen Valley High School, earned perfect scores on his Advanced Placement (AP) Exam in spring 2015.
	 
Cao was 1 of only 12 students in the world to earn every point possible on the AP Calculus AB Exam. Looking across approximately 4.5 million AP Exams taken by 2.5 million U.S. public high school students in 2015, only 322 students earned every point possible on an AP exam, a rare accomplishment.
	 
	 
	 
	 
	 
NBC Interview Link: 
Anton: http://www.nbcbayarea.com/on-air/as-seen-on/ESUHSD-Student-One-of-12-to-Earn-Perfect-AP-Calculus-Score_Bay-Area-373912061.html

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PRESENTATION
PREPARED BY:
Rebecca Huang, Student - Piedmont Hills High School
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Presentation and Discussion regarding Student Petition from Piedmont Hills High School Requesting to Add English 4 Back to the Master Schedule
	 
	 
The Early Assessment Program (EAP) is a collaborative effort among three important state entities in California: California State University (CSU), California Department of Education (CDE), and California State Board of Education (SBE). The goal of this unprecedented partnership is to ensure that college bound high-school graduates have the English and mathematics skills expected by the state university. Like most public comprehensive universities, CSU admits students first—and only then tests them to see if they have the reading, writing, and mathematics skills needed for placement in college-level study. If they do not, the students are placed in remedial courses for one or two semesters—thus making the pursuit of a baccalaureate degree more expensive for both the student and the state. 
	 
The EAP will allow students, their teachers, their parents, and the CSU to know exactly how well prepared the 11th-graders are for university-level work. Furthermore, it will give high school students a chance to polish their skills before enrolling in college. The EAP has three components: early testing, the opportunity for additional preparation in the 12th grade, and professional development activities for high school English and mathematics teachers. The EAP test is embedded in the California Assessment of Student Performance and Progress (CAASPP) 11th-grade English Language Arts/Literacy and mathematics. These tests are part of California’s public school testing and accountability system and are required of all grade 11 students. CAASPP exams cover both California high school standards as well as the CSU placement standards. Specified levels of these scores indicate meeting CSU standards. After 11th-graders take the test, they will be notified whether they have either met the CSU expectations (and are thus exempt from any additional CSU placement tests) or whether they need additional preparation in order to be successful in college-level work. 
	 
Those who need extra work can take the ERWC (Expository Reading and Writing Course) in their Senior year.  In 2003, a task force of a dozen high school teachers and administrators and California State University (CSU) faculty members began developing the Expository Reading and Writing Course (ERWC)--a rigorous, rhetorically based, full-year college preparatory English course for high school seniors designed to support college-readiness in English for California's diverse students. The course was published by The California State University Press (1st edition, 2008; 2nd edition 2013) and has currently been adopted by upwards of 700 comprehensive high schools throughout the state. Notably, the ERWC aligns with the California Common Core State Standards for English Language Arts and Literacy, addresses critical academic literacy challenges identified by the CSU English Placement Test Committee and ICAS (the Intersegmental Committee of the Academic Senates of the three segments of public higher education in California), and successfully prepares students to meet the academic demands and expectations of college and university faculty.
	 
Students who complete the ERWC course will be better prepared to pass the placement exam to the CSU and may also be exempted from taking the placement exam.
	 
The ERWC course is not an honors course. The course is not a remedial course. It is a college-prep, common core aligned course.
	 
	 
Recommendation:  
Take the results of the petition back to the English Department Chairs and work with the Subject Area Coordinator to develop a recommendation to IPC (Instructional Program Committee).

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent, Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services,  Julio Lucas, District Architect
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Presentation, Discussion, and/or Action regarding Authorization to Enter into Negotiations for Joint Use Transportation Yard Agreement at Franklin-McKinley School District
	 
	 
Franklin-McKinley School District (FMSD) owns vacant land adjacent to the existing FMSD Transportation Yard and Franklin Elementary School, 420 Tully Road, San Jose, CA 95111. In order to provide more centralized transportation facilities for the high school community, East Side Union High School District (ESUHSD) is interested in exploring possible shared use opportunities with FMSD.
	 
Staff from FMSD and ESUHSD have been investigating the possibility of developing a joint use shared transportation yard. This presentation is a result of those discussions and introduces an innovative concept of a joint use transportation yard. The intent is to illustrate how both FMSD and ESUHSD can benefit in sharing common facilities. We believe the proposed plan will benefit both districts in future cost savings by providing shared operational cost and more efficient use of the overall facility.
	 
The joint use shared transportation yard will include new safe professional transportation facilities and reliable, efficient, and cost-effective transportation services for ESUHSD Staff and Drivers. 
	 
Preliminary estimates show that building and equipping a new joint use shared transportation yard at Franklin Elementary School can be accomplished for approximately $4.3 million dollars.
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
$4.3 Million
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Fund 35
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees designate and authorize the Superintendent or his designee to negotiate and enter into, subject to Board ratification, a joint use lease agreement with Franklin-McKinley School District for the property at 420 Tully Road, San Jose, CA 95111, for the purpose of developing a joint use shared Transportation Yard.
items.item_recommendation: It is recommended that the Board of Trustees designate and authorize the Superintendent or his designee to negotiate and enter into, subject to Board ratification, a joint use lease agreement with Franklin-McKinley School District for the property at 420 Tully Road, San Jose, CA 95111, for the purpose of developing a joint use shared Transportation Yard.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Presentation, Discussion and/or Action regarding District Property and 
Other Land Use, 830 N. Capitol Avenue, San Jose, CA  95133 - Update #3
	 
	 
Per direction of the Board of Trustees at the November 19, 2015, Board meeting, staff is bringing back this item for discussion and action by the Board.
	 
Based on continued investigation and changes to the Independence High School Charter mitigation plan, the rationale for the mixed-use proposal is:
	 
Cost-effective and efficient use of District land
Provide mitigation relief to Independence High School
Provide community access to athletic fields
Provides critical housing to employees
Potential revenue generator for District
	 
Based on the discussion and action at the November 19 Board meeting, the Board authorized Administration to undertake the following tasks in furtherance of the development and/or redevelopment of the Education Center property, with progress updates to the Board on each of the below items on no less than a quarterly basis, and provided that no funds are spent in performing the below tasks:
	 
Engage Santa Clara County in preliminary discussions to determine level and scope of interest in possible shared-use field or soccer field on County land adjoining Education Center.
		 
Further research development of staff housing on Education Center property as a component of an overall development or redevelopment strategy; engage bargaining units in exploring staff housing development.
		 
Continue with process to design a potential new school; engage and enlist ESTA and other interested staff with that process.
		 
Develop and present to the Board a protocol for community engagement in connection with the possible development/redevelopment of the Education Center property.
		 
Explore possible joint use concepts with Franklin McKinley School District and Alum Rock Union Elementary School District for relocation of Corp Yard and Transportation.
		 
Develop financial pro forma(s) for recommended development scenario(s) for Board consideration.
	 
 Today, Administration is reporting back on activities completed to date.
	 
	 
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
Administration recommends that the Board authorize and approve Administration to submit a Preliminary Review Application to the Planning Commission for the City of San Jose not to exceed $4,500.

EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent, and Marisa Hanson, ESTA President
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Adopt Resolution #2015/2016-21 The Children’s Education and Health Care Protection Act of 2016 (Prop 30 Extension)
	 
	 
In 2012, Prop. 30, was passed, which helped public education recover some of the funds it lost during the recession by allowing districts to hire more teachers, faculty and education support professionals; brought additional books and supplies directly to the classroom; reopened school libraries; and improved student access to community college courses, while at the same time helped to stabilize California’s budget. 
	 
California continues to lag far behind the rest of the country in education funding, ranking 46th in per-student spending. Governor Brown’s 2016-17 budget forecasts show that unless we extend the tax on the wealthiest Californians, our schools and colleges will come up nearly $5 billion short in the first year, and the state budget will face a nearly $3 billion deficit. 
	 
The Children’s Education and Health Care Protection Act is not a new tax, but temporarily extends the income tax rates already in place on the wealthiest Californians and only affects the top 2% of earners in the state. The tax increases will automatically expire after 12 years.  The measure is expected to raise $8-11 billion a year that will go directly into a special fund that supports K-12 education and community colleges. 
	 
Administration is recommending that the Board of Trustees adopt Resolution #2015/2016-21 The Children's Education and Health Care Protection Act of 2016 (Prop 39 extension).
	 
	 
	 
	 
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees adopt resolution #2015/2016-21 The Children's Education and Health Care Protection Act of 2016 (Prop 30 extension).

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Karen Poon, Director of Finance, and Kelly Kwong, Senior Manager of Internal Controls
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Authorize Santa Teresa High School Grad Nite Committee, a School Connected Organization, to Solicit Contributions or Funds per Education Code 51520(a) and 51521 for the Santa Teresa High School Grad Nite Committee
	 
	 
 
A School Connected Organization (“SCO”) is a separately organized and controlled non-profit entity that raises funds for student programs.  SCOs are frequently organized and known as “booster” clubs and parent/teacher/student associations.  SCO are not controlled by or overseen by the District.  The law requires, however, that SCO must obtain District approval to solicit funds on the District's school sites for the benefit of students, or if it solicits funds on the representation that the money received is to be used in whole or in part for the benefit of students or any other District school or students.
	 
Education Code section 51520(a) provides: 
“During school hours, and within one hour before the time of opening and within one hour after the time of closing of school, pupils of the public school shall not be solicited on school premises by teachers or others to subscribe or contribute to the funds of, to become members of, or to work for, any organization not directly under the control of the school authorities, unless the organization is a nonpartisan, charitable organization organized for charitable purposes by an act of Congress or under the laws of the state, the purpose of the solicitation is nonpartisan and charitable, and the solicitation has been approved by the county board of education or by the governing board of the school district in which the school is located.” (Emphasis added.)
	 
Education Code section 51521 further provides in part: 
“No person shall solicit any other person to contribute to any fund or to purchase any item of personal property, upon the representation that the money received is to be used wholly or in part for the benefit of any public school or the student body of any public school, unless such person obtains the prior written approval of either the governing board of the school district in which such solicitation is to be made or the governing board of the school district having jurisdiction over the school or student body represented to be benefited by such solicitation, or the designee of either of such boards.”
	 
In addition, Board Policy 1230 School Connected Organizations states, “Persons proposing to establish a school-connected organization shall submit a request to the Governing Board for authorization to operate at the school… Requests for subsequent authorization shall be presented to the Superintendent or designee annually…”
	 
After a review of Santa Teresa High School Grad Nite Committee financials and other criteria, the Administration recommends that the Board authorize Santa Teresa High School Grad Nite Committee to solicit contributions or funds on any District site for the benefit of any District students or programs. 
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees authorize Santa Teresa High School Grad Nite Committee, a School Connected Organization, pursuant to Education Code 51520(a) and 51521 to solicit contributions or funds on any District site for nonpartisan and charitable purposes for the benefit of District students or programs.

TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and Karen Poon, Director of Finance 
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to approve Charter School Proposition 39 Facilities Use Agreement with DCP Charter High School               
	 
	 
On or before November 1, 2015, the District received a request for reasonably equivalent facilities for the 2016-2017 school year from DCP Charter High School (“DCP”).  DCP currently operates its charter program at the District’s Independence High School campus, and its current facility use agreement with the District expires June 30, 2016.  DCP, like most of the District’s charter schools, is allocated facilities on a yearly basis by the District. 
	 
This year, instead of adhering to the timelines for facilities allocation under the Proposition 39 and its implementing regulations, the District and DCP agreed to enter into a modified process to review DCP’s facilities request and needs, discuss an allocation of Prop, 39 facilities to DCP that meets DCP’s needs and the District’s available resources, and consider a 3-5 year facilities use agreement which would allow the District and DCP to better plan and facilitate charter school programs and uses on District sites.
	 
The District and DCP have now reached agreement for continued Prop. 39 facilities for DCP at Independence High School.  Administration proposes a five (5) year facility use agreement for DCP at the Independence site for the term July 1, 2016 – June 30, 2021.  The agreement is conditioned upon DCP maintaining its charter in good standing and DCP continuing to pay its pro rata share of facilities costs as authorized by Prop. 39.  The facilities include both “Dedicated Space” (classroom and administrative facilities for DCP’s exclusive use in connection with its education program) and equitable shared use of other site facilities (including, for example, gyms, multi-purpose room, theatre, parking, athletic fields) to be used in connection with DCP’s academic and athletic program, and for no other purpose.
	 
The Administration requests authority to negotiate and enter into a Facilities Use Agreement with DCP for a five (5) year term in accordance with the District’s form Facilities Use Agreement (copy attached) subject to subsequent ratification by the Board.
	 
	 
	 
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
To be determined. 
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees authorize Administration to negotiate and enter into a Facilities Use Agreement for charter school facilities with DCP  for a five (5) year term at the Independence High School site in accordance with with the District's form Facilities Use Agreement and subject to subsequent ratification by the Board.
items.item_recommendation: It is recommended that the Board of Trustees authorize Administration to negotiate and enter into a Facilities Use Agreement for charter school facilities with DCP for a five (5) year term at the Independence High School site in accordance with the District's form Facilities Use Agreement and subject to subsequent ratification by the Board.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Cari Vaeth, Associate Superintendent of Human Resources
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Approve Increase to Certificated Substitute Services Rates, Effective August 1, 2016
	 
The district is having difficulty recruiting and retaining certificated substitute teachers.  Because of the shortage of teachers throughout the county, substitutes who have the ability to obtain a credential have been hired as regular classroom teachers.  Compounding the problem is the substitute rate of pay.  A survey of all school districts in Santa Clara County indicated that our rates, while not the lowest, are not competitive.  The District has not increased the pay rates since 2008.
	 
Currently, the District pays substitutes at the following rates:
$135 per day for day-to-day substitute teachers
$145 per day after the 15th consecutive day served in multiple assignments
$155 per day for long-term assignments (The long-term rate is based on 16 consecutive days of substitute teaching in one assignment.)  The rate is retroactive to the first day of the assignment.
To improve our competitiveness in securing substitutes, it is recommended that the District increase the substitute rates to the following levels:
$150 per day for day-to-day substitute teachers
$170 per day after the 20th consecutive day served in multiple assignment.  The rate is not retroactive to the first day of the assignment but stays in effect for the remainder of each semester.
$200 per day for long-term assignments (The long-term rate is based on 20 consecutive days of substitute teaching in one assignment.)  The rate is retroactive to the first day of the assignment.
In addition to the above recommendations, the District is also recommending an increase in the substitute rates at the following levels for retirees from the East Side Union High School District.  
From $155 per day to $175 per day for short-term rate (day-to-day assignments).
From $175 per day to $225 per day for long-term rate.  (The long-term rate is based on five teaching periods and 20 consecutive days of substitute teaching in one assignment).  This rate is retroactive to the first day of the consecutive substitute assignment.  
We believe the increase in the substitute rates for retirees would encourage fully-credentialed retirees, who are familiar with our district, to serve as substitutes.  
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Approximately $215,000
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Various
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the new certificated substitute services rates, effective August 1, 2016.

Attached for the Board's review is the proposed classified, classified management and certificated administrative holiday schedule for the 2016-2017 school calendar.
	 
The California School Employees Association (CSEA), Chapter 187, on behalf of classified employees, and the District have reached a tentative agreement on the holiday schedule and are requesting final approval from the Board of Trustees.  The proposed holiday schedule includes the contractual holidays, plus three additional paid holidays during Christmas Break.  It also includes three days during the leave where employees will have the option of charging annual leave, floating holiday, compensatory time or leave without pay.  This arrangement will enable the District to shutdown all operations during the two-week break, which will result in savings in utility costs.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
		 
		 
		 
		 
TO:
Board of Trustees
						 
FROM:
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
						 
						 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, André Bell, Director of Purchasing and Capital Accounting, Janice Unger, Capital Projects Purchasing Manager, and Carlos Salazar, Senior Projects Manager
						 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Approve the Project and Award a Contract for Design-Build Services for the Districtwide Fire Alarm Modernization Project
		 
On April 16, 2015, the Board of Trustees, pursuant to Education Code §17250.20, adopted Resolution #2014/2015-21 to use the design-build delivery method for the Districtwide Fire Alarm Modernization Project (Item 15.04). 
		 
Request for Proposals
The District developed a Request for Proposals (RFP) to procure design and construction of the Districtwide Fire Alarm Project.  The RFP specified that the following selection criteria were to be considered in selecting the Design-Build Entity (DBE) whose proposal demonstrated the “best value” to the District, as defined in Education Code §17250.15.  The “best value” basis of evaluation allows the District to select a DBE based on more than price alone, one of the advantages of design-build in comparison to traditional delivery methods.  The first five criteria are required by Education Code §17250.15, the code section under which this design-build project is to be awarded.  The additional criteria, which are critical to the success of the project, were added at the District’s discretion.
		 
                FACTORS                                                                             MAXIMUM POINTS
Price                                                                                           20 points
Technical Expertise                                                                      5 points
Life Cycle Costs over 25 Years                                                  10 points
Skilled Labor Force Availability                                                  10 points
Acceptable Safety Record                                                           5 points
Schedule                                                                                    20 points
Engineering and Design Innovation                                             5 points
Project Management Plan                                                           5 points
Program Requirements                                                             20 points
		 
                              TOTAL (Maximum)          100 points
		 
The RFP was issued to qualified DBEs. Three DBEs responded to the Project Specific Request for Qualification Process, out of which Two DBEs elected to participate in the design and cost competition set forth in the District’s Request for Proposal published on December 17, 2015. The Request for Proposal included RFP Criteria Documents and Project Scoping information prepared by the District’s Fire Alarm System Consultants, Interface Engineering. On February 3, 2016, the District received proposals from two DBEs:
Alten Construction, Inc. DBE (“Alten”)
Gonsalves & Stronck Construction Company, Inc. (“G&S”)
		 
Re-programing and Re-scoping upon Preliminary Review
Upon performing a preliminary review of the Proposals, the District determined that the Proposal Prices submitted by the two DBEs exceeded the budgeted amounts for design and construction of the project. The Proposal Price consists of the costs for Base Scope, Solicited Alternates, and Unsolicited Alternates. The original Program and Scope of Work were re-evaluated and the District decided to reduce the Base Scope of work and to further delineate Solicited Alternates, at various Districtwide sites, that the District could select based on existing condition of the Fire Alarm System and the priority for modernization. Based on the re-programmed and re-scoped work, the DBEs were requested to submit additional information and clarifications on their Proposals that would enable the District to select the Base Scope and the highest priority Solicited Alternate scope items that could be procured within the available design and construction budget amount. Alten and G&S submitted their revised Proposal information and clarifications on March 3, 2016. 
		 
Proposal Evaluation Summary
The assessment of District staff, Fire Alarm System consultants Interface Engineering, and construction management staff from Swinerton Management & Consulting, is that while both Proposals, along with the additional information and clarifications, are responsive to the RFP, G&S’s proposal provides the ‘Best Value’ to the District.  The following summarizes the District’s assessment of the nine evaluation factors, which were described in the RFP. 
		 
Price:  Each Design-Build Entity could earn a maximum of Twenty (20) points in this category. A maximum of nineteen (19) points could be earned by the DBE offering the Best value by designing and constructing the Project as described in the Request for Proposal, including RFP Criteria Documents satisfy all other Design-Build Entity obligations under the Contract Documents. A further maximum of one (1) point could be earned from the value offered in the unsolicited alternates included in the proposal.
		 
G&S’s proposal offers the Base Scope of work at a substantially lower Proposal Price, thereby allowing the District to select high priority Solicited Alternate scope items at four sites. Notification and Detection Modernization at Andrew Hill, Independence, Silver Creek and Yerba Buena can be achieved as part of the Project scope, thereby providing more value to the District for the available budgeted amounts.  Alten’s proposal offers Base Scope at a comparatively higher Proposal Price, thereby not allowing the District the option of selecting as many Solicited Alternates. G&S received 18 points and Alten received 15 points in this Price category.
		 
Technical Expertise: Each DBE could earn a maximum score of Five (5) points in this category based on the qualifications of its team. 
		 
Both teams proposed experienced teams of project managers, engineers, subcontractors, specialty consultants, and specialty subcontractors to design and construct this project. Alten received 4.38 points and G&S received 4.31 points in this category.
		 
Life Cycle Costs: Each DBE could earn a maximum score of Ten (10) points in this category, by proposing facilities whose sustainable design results in a low life cycle cost as calculated over a twenty-five (25) year period.  The life cycle cost calculation includes the first cost of the project, annual testing and certification, repair and monitoring costs, and replacement costs of any systems/components whose service lives do not exceed twenty-five (25) years. 
		 
G&S’s proposal provides lower projected Life Cycle Costs, including initial costs, annual costs and replacement costs, compared to Alten.  Alten received 9 points and G&S received 10 points in this category.
		 
Skilled Labor Force: Each DBE could earn a maximum of Ten (10) points by satisfying the requirements for “skilled labor force availability” as defined in California Education Code Section 17250.10 – 17250.50.  Each was asked to evidence in its Proposal a commitment to furthering these goals:  1) maximizing opportunities for local, small and emerging businesses to compete fairly for work associated with this Project; 2) maximizing opportunities for local workers to be employed on the Project and ensuring adequate staffing for this project given the current competitive market conditions.
		 
Both proposals demonstrated commitment to the District’s Project Labor Agreement, requirement for student internships, and commitment to a local workforce. Alten’s proposal included a second Electrical subcontractor, thereby providing additional skilled staff strength.  Alten received 10 points and G&S received 9.50 points in this category.
		 
Acceptable Safety Record: Each DBE could earn a maximum score of Five (5) points in this category.  Two (2) points could be earned by demonstrating an acceptable safety record.  An additional six (3) points could be earned by submitting a superior Project Safety Plan (PSP), evidencing an exceptionally comprehensive Injury & Illness Prevention Plan (IIPP), and having a low Experience Modification Factor rating. 
		 
A key metric of an acceptable safety record is a contractor’s Experience Modification Rate (EMR), which is a measure of the frequency of accidents and injuries that a contractor has incurred on a historical basis.  Both Alten and G&S have EMR better than the industry average of 1.0, but G&S’s average EMR is significantly better and superior to Alten’s.  G&S failed to provide evidence of an IIPP and a Project-specific Safety Plan. Alten received 5 points and G&S received 4.31 points in this category.
		 
Schedule: Each DBE could earn a maximum of Twenty (20) points by proposing creative scheduling that will reduce the overall length of time of construction, provide most efficient coordination with other CIP projects Districtwide, as well as minimize the impact on the sites as a whole. 
		 
Both DBEs propose aggressive project schedules that generally meet the requirements of the RFP.  Alten’s proposed scheduled offered more realistic Start Date and meets certain key milestones, compared to G&S’s schedule. Alten received 19.75 points and G&S received 19.00 points in this category.
		 
Engineering and Design Innovation: Each DBE could earn a maximum of Five (5) points in this category, through the quality of their design solutions as well as the level of innovation reflected in each DBE’s design solution, and its overall approach to constructing the Project. 
		 
Alten and G&S proposes very similar Fire Alarm System configuration and schematic design since they both propose to use the services of the same specialty Fire Alarm subcontractor. Alten received 4.44 points and G&S received 4.50 points in this category.
		 
Project Management Plan: Each DBE could earn a maximum of Five (5) points by evidencing superiority in their proposed logistics plan, quality assurance/quality control plan, structure of organizational chart, knowledge/skill/ability/experience of key personnel, Owner/DBE interaction strategies, and other aspects of project management. 
		 
Both Alten and G&S’s proposals include information that conveys their respective Project Management Plans adequately. Alten’s proposal includes the required information such as logistics, owner-DBE interaction, workforce and work hours. G&S proposal offers a superior understanding of the project sites and offers a preliminary logistics plan. Alten received 4.88 points and G&S received 4.38 points in this category.
		 
Program Requirements: The Program Requirements were established by the District, in light of other CIP work ongoing and anticipated at Districtwide sites. The Program Requirements were communicated to the DBEs through the RFP, which included the RFP Criteria Documents, Division 00 and 01 Documents, and District’s Design and Construction Standards. Each DBE could earn a maximum of Twenty (20) points by proposing a design that achieves the project’s program requirements as specified in the RFP. 
		 
G&S’s proposal best meets the program requirements by allowing substantially more scope of work, including Base Scope and Solicited Alternates to be performed within the available design-construction budget amount.  Alten’s proposal allows less scope of work to be performed within the available budget. G&S’s proposal provides more value to the Districtwide CIP as it will allow four additional sites to receive FA notification and detection modernization, as high priority Solicited Alternate scope items. This in turn will help support other CIP modernization projects at these sites.  Alten earned 19 points and G&S earned 19.25 points in this category.    
		 
		 
Based on the proposal evaluation described above, the final score (rounded to two decimal points) for each DBE is as follows:

Best and Final Proposal Negotiations
The RFP specified that following the scoring of each DBE’s proposal, at which time the DBE whose proposal is deemed most responsive to the RFP was determined, and pursuant to Education Code §17250.25(a)(2)(v), the District reserved the right to hold discussions or negotiations with that DBE for the purpose of receiving clarification and/or modification to their proposal, in order to achieve a resulting Best and Final Proposal that could be recommended to the Board of Trustees for contract award.
		 
G&S’s original proposal offered an efficient solution to the program requirements for the Districtwide Fire Alarm Modernization Project. G&S’s Proposal Price for the Base Scope of work and select high-priority alternates were within the design-construction budget, and provided opportunities for the District to select appropriate and high priority alternates for inclusion into the contract.  
		 
The District’s project team, including the construction managers and the Fire Alarm System engineering consultants worked with the District’s Facilities Department to determine which Solicited and Unsolicited Alternates, proposed by G&S, would be procured through the best and final proposal. Solicited Alternates included in the final contract scope of work are 1) Notification and Detection Modernization at Andrew Hill, 2) Notification and Detection Modernization at Independence, 3) Notification and Detection Modernization at Silver Creek, 4) Notification and Detection Modernization at Yerba Buena, 5) Fire Alarm system Testing/Inspection/Preventive Maintenance/Certification, 6) Fire Alarm System Corrective Maintenance, 7) Drafted Auto CADD drawings full and complete in vector file format. The Unsolicited Alternate items listed by G&S did not provide significant value; hence they were not selected. Based on the District’s selection of the Base Scope and the Solicited Alternate scope items, G&S submitted their Best and Final Proposal on March 31, 2016.
		 
Since the proposed Fire Alarm System Modernization work would be closely interrelated to the ongoing and required Fire Alarm system service, maintenance and certification through the course of the proposed contract and warranty duration, District staff determined that by including the Fire Alarm System service and maintenance as part of the Design-Build contract, the District would receive benefit of a single point of responsibility and receive enhanced coordination during the course of the modernization work. Therefore Solicited Alternate scope of work items 1) Fire Alarm system Testing/Inspection/Preventive Maintenance/Certification and 2) Fire Alarm System Corrective Maintenance are included as part of the Design-Build Contract. The costs for this scope of work shall be funded by Fund 03.
		 
G&S’s Best and Final Proposal to design and construct the Districtwide Fire Alarm Modernization Project, including Base Scope and Solicited Alternates, is $17,195,678.
		 
		 
Stipend
A stipend is an amount paid by the owner to those responsive proposers who are unsuccessful in obtaining contract award. A stipend enhances competition to generate market interest in the project from the most highly qualified DBEs, helps defray costly proposal development incurred by DBEs, signals the intent that the owner is serious about carrying the project forward, and encourages proposers to expend the time, money and resources to provide a more creative and comprehensive solution.  The Design-Build Institute of America is an industry organization that defines, teaches and promotes best practices in design-build; this organization recommends the payment of stipends as a best practice.  In the Federal sector, OMB Circular No. A-11 (2006) encourages the use of stipends for reasons described above.
		 
The RFP stipulated that if the District awards a Contract for the Project, the District will pay a Stipend in the amount of $5,000 to each non-successful Design-Build Entity that submits a Proposal which is deemed by the District to be responsive and responsible. Alten submitted a responsive and responsible Proposal, and should be awarded the $5,000 Stipend if the District awards a Contract to G&S.
		 
                                                                                                                               
FISCAL IMPACT:

RECOMMENDATION:
Based on the foregoing, it is recommended that the Board of Trustees:
Adopt the above Proposal Evaluation Summary as its findings
Approve the project and award a design-build contract for the Districtwide Fire Alarm Modernization Project, to Gonsalves & Stronck Construction Company, Inc., in the amount of $17,195,678.00;
Process the contract through two Purchase Orders:
Part of the contract, specifically related to the design and construction of the Fire Alarm Modernization work be processed through a Purchase Order for the amount of $ 15,736,478.00
Part of this contract, specifically for the scope of work consisting of Fire Alarm system Testing/Inspection/Preventive Maintenance/Certification and Fire Alarm System Corrective Maintenance be processed through a Purchase Order for the amount of $ 1,459,200.00
Approve payment of the $5,000 stipend to Alten Construction, Inc., DBE for its responsive participation in the design and cost competition

SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Approve the Measure I General Obligation Bond Distribution for KIPP San Jose Collegiate Charter School (Restoration of Unfunded Measure E Allocation)
	 
	 
Under Proposition 39, KIPP San Jose Collegiate Charter School is eligible for the District’s Measure I General Obligation Bond proceeds.  Bond funds may only be used to improve District buildings and properties and/or to provide appropriate equipment.  On February 19, 2009, the Board of Trustees approved a Measure E Prioritization List that allocated up to $215,067 to KIPP San Jose Collegiate Charter School (Board item 13.03).  This request is asking for a distribution of $36,000.00, which will leave a remaining allocation balance of $56,237.
	 
KIPP serves 475 students.  Of those students, 420 reside within East Side Union High School District boundaries.  KIPP has identified a need for 105 Chromebooks and 3 YES Mini-laptop carts. Any funding balance will be used for future provision of furniture and/or equipment, upon KIPP’s request.

SUBJECT:
Receive the first Quarterly Report on Williams Uniform Complaints for Period Covering January 1, 2016 through March 31, 2016, as required by EC 35186 (Williams Settlement Legislation SB550 and AB2727)
	 
BACKGROUND
As a result of the Williams Case (EC 35186), referred to as a landmark Superior Court case, requires that every California public school provide each student with, at the very least, sufficient textbooks and instructional materials; clean, safe and functional buildings and facilities; and permanent, appropriately trained and assigned teachers. 
	 
School districts shall support summarized data on the nature and resolution of all Williams Complaints on a quarterly basis to the governing board and the county superintendent of schools.  The report shall include the number of complaints by general subject area with the number of resolved and unresolved complaints.
	 
The attached report indicates the number of complaints, if any, filed from January 1, 2016, through March 31, 2016. 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
None
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Senate Bill 6 (Williams)
State Instructional Materials Allocation
District Instructional Materials Budget
Other Categorical funds as Appropriate
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
The Administration recommends that the Governing Board accept the First Quarterly Williams Settlement Uniform Complaint Report for the period covering January 1, 2016, through March 31, 2016, as required by EC 35186 (Williams Settlement Legislation SB550 and AB2727).

Glenn Vander Zee, Assistant Superintendent of Educational Services, and Nguyet Dinh, Administrator of Minority Language Programs
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Approve Academic Criterion for Reclassification of English Learners to English Proficient Students for the 2015-2016 School Year
	 
Consequent to the implementation of the Common Core State Standards and the California Assessment of Student Performance and Progress (CAASPP), Assembly Bill (AB) 484 suspended the California Standards Test (CST). Since CST can no longer be used as a criterion to reclassify English learners to English proficient students, the California Department of Education directed school districts to select another measure to replace the CST.
	 
For the 2015-2016 school year, three of the four reclassification criteria remain unchanged:
	 
1.  Assessment of English language proficiency, using an objective assessment instrument, including but not limited to, the state test of English language development.   
2. Teacher evaluation, including but not limited to, a review of the student’s curriculum mastery
3.   Parent opinion and consultation
	 
The fourth criterion requires a comparison of student performance on an objective assessment of basic skills in English-language arts. The assessments results must have an empirically established range of performance in basic skills based on the performance of English proficient students of the same age.
	 
School districts may identify assessments they will use to determine that English learners are meeting academic measures that indicate they are ready to reclassify. These assessment instruments need to measure basic skills for all students and produce results that show whether a student is performing at or close to grade level. Regulations also specify that local reclassification criteria must be reviewed by the school district committee on programs and services for English learners. 
	 
A district team convened to review English learners’ reclassification data, assessment instruments, and cut scores that can be used as the academic criterion for reclassification. The proposed criterion was reviewed and recommended based on the guidelines from the California Department of Education.

SUBJECT:
Approve California Interscholastic Federation (CIF) Application for Renewal of 2016-2017 Multi-School Membership
	 
Pursuant to California Interscholastic Federation regulations, CIF-member schools may allow only students currently enrolled, in grades 9-12, in their school, to participate in any CIF competition.  Any CIF-member school that wishes to allow participation on its team(s) by students, who are currently enrolled in non-CIF-member schools or programs which do not offer any interscholastic athletic programs (i.e. small but necessary schools), may request approval to do so.
	 
The administrative responsibility for all students involved in athletics shall rest with the Principal of the CIF-member school for which the student(s) is competing.  Students must meet all the CIF-member scholastic eligibility requirements.
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
$15,353.04
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
General Fund

It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the California Interscholastic Federation Application for Renewal of 2016-2017 Multi-School Membership.

EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, André Bell, Director of Purchasing and Capital Accounting, and Janice Unger, Capital Projects Purchasing Manager
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Receive Explanation for the Change Orders to the Lease-Leaseback Contracts with McCarthy Building Companies, Inc., for Independence High School – Performing Arts Center Bldg. F, Modernization Building B Commons, and Building B Demolition and Site Improvement Projects
	 
This written report is in response to the request made by a Board of Trustee Member at the March 3, 2016 board meeting about the criteria for recommending approval of change orders to amend the McCarthy Building Companies, Inc. (MBC) Lease-Leaseback Contracts.  According to the lease-leaseback (LLB) contract there are four major conditions that could generate a change order to the LLB contract.
	 
Unforeseen Conditions – Are unanticipated work items required to complete the project that was not discoverable during the curse of design. Typical unforeseen conditions may be discovered while performing underground work and work within the building shell that were different from the original plans.  These items are not visible until they become exposed.
Owner Listed Anticipated Items – This is for known anticipated scope items, such as repair areas that cannot be fully determined until construction exposes the actual as-is condition.
Added Owner Scope – This is for owner added items.
Extraordinary Design Issues – This is for Architectural/Engineer design error or omissions items that could not be determined during the constructability review process due engineering calculation errors or DSA code compliant issues.
The above listed items are considered when reviewing a change order request from the LLB contractor. Listed below are the percentage allocations of the contract amount for these four conditions for each of the three LLB projects at Independence.
	 
IH Modernization Performing Arts Center Change Orders No. 1 through 10
                  Unforeseen Conditions                       1.88%
                  Owner Allowances                               .29%
                  Owner Added Scope                          5.74%
                  Extraordinary Design Error                  .22%
                  Total percentage
                  of contract amount                            8.13%
	 
IH Modernization Building B Commons Change Order No. 1
                  Unforeseen Conditions                       .48%

                  Owner Added Scope                         1.40%
                  Extraordinary Design Error                     0%

IH Building B Demolition and Site Improvement Change Order No. 1
                  Unforeseen Conditions                         .82%

                  of contract amount                              5.03%
	 
It should be noted that there are adequate funds available in the project budgets to cover all of these change orders.
	 
To further explain the justification for these change orders, the following are the reasons:
	 
IH Modernization Performing Arts Center Change Orders No. 1 through 10
Owner Added Scope consists of:
Addition of waste baskets and site benches to allow better gathering areas for students and theater goers
The audio visual equipment was intentionally not specified during the design process so that the most current up to date equipment could be installed.
This category also included the cost for the changes required by DSA at submission
Modification of lobby soffit and custom sized marker boards to provide a better student experience
Additional site paving replacement was needed so to improve the approach the building
Replacement of controls and valve boxes to ensure proper function of the chiller system
Added an energy management systems to better and efficiently control the building
	 
IH Modernization Building B Commons Change Order No. 1
Owner Added Scope consists of:
This category included the cost for the changes required by DSA at submission and the addition of white boards and projectors were due to a district standard change shortly after design.
	 
IH Building B Demolition and Site Improvement Change Order No. 1
Owner Added Scope consists of:
Additional asphalt replacement at north drive entry at Jackson St. to provide a wider and safer entrance to the campus
Provide additional enhanced landscaping along the entry points to buildings
These listed above are more significant change orders in terms of cost.  During the course of construction the design team which includes the Architect and his Engineers, the Construction Manager, and Facilities staff review every potential change order to confirm the need to recommend for approval.  In general, the criteria used are: life safety and structural concerns, cost, schedule impact, and most important how does it improve and benefit the end users.
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not applicable

Not applicable
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
Not applicable

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, André Bell, Director of Purchasing and Capital Accounting, and Janice Unger, Capital Projects Purchasing Manager
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Budget Summary for the Education Center Interior/Exterior Facility Improvements
	 
This written report is in response to the request made by a Board of Trustee Member at the March 3, 2016, board meeting about the improvements (interior/exterior) at the EC Center.
	 
The Education Center Interior/Exterior construction and equipment was budgeted at $825,000 and was approved as part of the district’s 2015-16 Adopted Budget.  The funds were approved as part of the Fund 35 allocation of expenditures totaling $3.125 million as noted on page 43 of the 2015-16 adopted budget as presented on June 18, 2015, Item 8.04.  The budget detail worksheet is also attached which provides the summary detail of the expenditures planned in Fund 35 for the 15-16 fiscal year.  The budget detail worksheet is an internal working budget document and is not included in the adopted budget book.
	 
The interior EC project scope involved the installation of new workstations, minor painting, minor carpet replacement, some ceiling tile replacements, and new cabling and data wiring.  The exterior EC improvements included painting the exterior, new signage near the street and at the entryway, new gates at the driveway, and parking lot repair, slurry seal, and striping.  Attached is an analysis for all internal and external work completed which has been submitted to the Board which totals $941,944.
	 
The Interior/Exterior project actually exceeded the estimated $825,000 budget by $116,944 as a result of an underestimate for the associated costs for electrical wiring and telecom data.  The wiring and cabling throughout the interior project areas was insufficient to support the new installation and loads as a result of the work completed.  Based on the overage, a capital project initiation/revision form which is attached was prepared and routed by the facilities department for review and approval.
	 
Fund 35 (School Facilities funds) is the District’s capital discretionary funds account which enables the district to support both bond and non-bond projects in accordance with education code.  Fund 35 is the district’s discretionary capital facilities fund and is managed very differently from the bond funds where the Board approves all bond projects in accordance with the prescribed bond language.  As a best practice, facility projects planned for funding from fund 25 and 35 should be included in the budget detail when the budget is adopted to promote greater transparency and clarity.    
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not applicable
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
Not applicable

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
	 
			 
			 
TO:
Board of Trustees
						 
						 
FROM:
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
						 
						 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services
						 
						 
SUBJECT:
Receive Update on Independence High School's Growth Impacts and Mitigations 
			 
			 
On February 4, 2016 (Board Item 8.05), the Board received a presentation on impacts of charter schools on Independence High School’s facilities.  The Board approved long and short term upgrades to mitigate those impacts, and requested updates on the following items.
			 
Independence High School Athletic Facilities
The approved new practice infield and batting cages will be welcomed additions to the softball and baseball facilities, allowing more teams to practice concurrently. Baseball Coach Bob Leadbetter proposed the idea, and even mocked up a recommended location near the sand volleyball court with painted line markings, bases and pitching mounds.  The field could be dirt, and serve as both softball and baseball infields.  With the closely mown grass and painted markings, the area is already providing additional practice space for concurrent use with the existing two softball and two baseball fields.  The painted mock up demonstrates that a practice infield will fit – a concern voiced by Physical Education (PE) staff.  The mock up also demonstrates that there remains space for new batting cages behind home plate.  There is also space at the east end of the natural turf athletic zone for batting cages.  Independence High School staff will be highly engaged with the design of these new facilities, to ensure that the needs of PE, men’s and women’s athletics are optimized.
			 
			 
Another concern voiced at the February 4, Board meeting was that the soccer field layout is not as shown on the presentation.  The graphic showed two side by side soccer fields, parallel to each other and perpendicular to Mabury Avenue.  That layout is the optimized layout designed when the field was renovated in 2013; there are permanent markers at the corners of each field to facilitate repainting of line markings at the beginning of each soccer season.  Last year, one field was marked in differently just for the 2015 soccer season to accommodate storm drainage improvements that were underway.  Those storm drain improvements have been installed, and future soccer field layout will return to the optimized one indicated on the presented graphic.
			 
			 
Independence High School Staff Restrooms Near Building K3
The availability of staff restrooms near Building K3 Science Classrooms was an articulated concern at the February 4th Board meeting.  The closest staff restroom is in adjacent Building H – the former school administration building; that building is scheduled to be under construction beginning Summer 2016, and the modernized facility will be six classrooms and no restrooms.  Concurrently, new restroom buildings L6 and H2 are in design and will be constructed, with beneficial occupancy scheduled for early November 2016.  The graphic below indicates the designed locations of those new restrooms, which will be comprised of student and staff toilet facilities.  Those new facilities will be reasonably close to the Building K complex, and are intended to serve the occupants in Buildings K, L, G and H at the west end of campus.  
			 
			 
Staff investigated the possibility of adding a single staff restroom in Building K3.  The addition of a single stall restroom would impede upon program space that was renovated in 2004 (floor plan graphic below).  If encroachment upon program space is acceptable in order to accommodate a restroom, the rough order of magnitude cost is $500,000.  If program space encroachment is unacceptable, a single staff restroom addition outside of the building would cost $600,000.  Site administration does not believe the benefit of a staff restroom in Building K3 justifies the cost, particularly in light of the new Restroom Buildings L6 and H2 that will be available soon.
			 
			 
In 2014-15, ACE and DCP charter schools occupied Building H; they are currently no longer occupying Building H.  As of February 2016, Building H is housing McCarthy Building Companies, Inc. – the construction contractor that is modernizing Building B1.  McCarthy was directed to remove their construction trailer in the Theater Plaza upon completion of the Theater modernization project, to relinquish that area of the campus back to school operations.  In lieu of encroaching upon school operations further, the District is housing McCarthy’s project administration staff in Building H.  As of February 29, the staff restroom in Building H is also available for Independence High School staff.  This newly implemented interim mitigation measure is providing access to a staff restroom close to Building K3, until Restroom Buildings L6 and H2 open in November; however, this interim measure will not be available in the Fall 2016 semester, because Building H modernization construction will be underway.
			 
IH Theater Use Policy
The theater is available to be rented by both internal and external users.  Reservation can be made using the District’s on line reservation system (http://facilitron.com/esuhsd95133).  The request must be approved by site administration. If theater equipment is needed for the event, it triggers the additional cost of the Light/Sound Technician ($30.00 per hour, minimum of 3 hours).  No students are allowed to operate this equipment without adult supervision.  There may be additional charges depending on additional equipment needed.
			 
Fiscal Impact:
Not applicable
			 
Funding Source:
Not applicable
			 
Recommendation:
Not applicable

TO:

FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Receive Payroll Department Operational Efficiency and Comparative Staffing Review
	 
	 
The District contracted with the accounting firm of Nigro & Nigro to conduct an organizational efficiency and comparative staffing review of the Payroll and Human Resources departments.  The objective of the review was to assess the existing organizational structures and the functions within each department as well as between departments.  The review was also designed to address the effectiveness and efficiency of the existing structure, as well as the adequacy of Payroll and Human Resources staffing levels in support of the educational program.  A number of findings and recommendations are provided by Nigro & Nigro and are attached for your review. 
	 
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable

Information only.
